    > @tayloramurphy its worth calling out that, as `env_aliases` is going away, this means the `MELTANO_DISABLE_TRACKING` env var is going too (as its a negated alias of `send_anonymous_usage_stats`). Possibly not the only visible change here, but worth calling out specifically for comment 🙂 I caught up briefly with @aaronsteers and we talked about adding a separate setting called `disable_tracking`, or renaming the existing `send_anonymous_usage_stats` to `disable_tracking` as possibilities.

_decoded_content.title: Update `meltano elt` for adapter-specific dbt plugins
_decoded_content.description:
The `meltano elt` command breaks in 2.0 for two potential reasons:

## Challenge `#1`: Due to `env_aliases` being deprecated, a `transform` plugin that references a `schema` variable will fail unless a schema is explicitly sent.

I think this is okay. 

We should be deprecating our own Meltano-managed `transform` plugins anyway, even if we don't fully remove `transforms` plugin support. Some community users have shown desire in managing/supporting their own `transform` plugins, which would lead us towards still supporting the functionality in a BYO capacity, but removing support for our Meltano-owned implementations, especially if they have known usability bugs like this one.

## Challenge `#2`: `elt` won't know which plugin to use for the transformer

Now that we have adapter-specific plugins for transformers, `meltano elt` likely will not find the transformer it's looking for.

## Proposal Update (2022-05-21):

Updated proposal is that we use the `3C` implementation below.

### Option 1: explicit transformer name per environment

To address this, one option is to provide an environment-level config like `default_transformer: dbt-snowflake` which tells Meltano which plugin to use on each environment.

- Challenge here is that `meltano elt` doesn't require an environment to be set.

### Option 2: explicit transformer name in `elt` and `schedule` operations

Another option is to add a CLI arg to `meltano elt` like `--transfomer=dbt-snowflake`. Note: legacy schedules in yaml would also need to provide a `transformer: dbt-snowflake` entry if we went this path.

### Option 3: `elt` replaced with `el` (`el+t` use cases go through `meltano run` and/or `jobs` definitions)

I'd also be in favor of removing `elt` support and renaming the command to `meltano el`. If we go this path, we'd have to simultaneously remove support for transformations in legacy schedules, but we could do this graceously so that the schedule definitions would only print a warning and still provide the core `el` capability. (Anything needing `el+t` would just use the new `jobs` paradigm.)

### Option 3B: `elt` throws an error if `--transform` is not `skip`

Same as Option 3, except no renaming and no changes to the CLI.

1. In `meltano elt`, we simply throw an error message if `--transform` is not `skip`.
2. Similarly in legacy extract/load schedules, we simply throw an error message if `transform: _` is anything other than `skip`.

### Option 3C: `elt` throws an error if `--transform` is not `skip` and no `dbt` plugin exists

Same as Option 3B, except the hard failure occurs only if no `transformer` plugin exists with the `name` (or `namespace`?) of _exactly_ `dbt`. Basically this keeps _existing_ projects working but for any new implementations, users will be guided by the error text to use `meltano run` instead.

And the same behavior would be applied for schedules, if the transform setting on the schedule is anything _except_ `skip` _and_ if no plugin with the exact name/namespace of `dbt` exists, then we throw the error message telling users to create a job for any `EL+T` use cases.

### Option 4: Some other solution using aliases, namespaces, or 'first transformer' logic

This is a little more hacky, imho, but we could also solve this problem by introducing logic by which meltano would select a reasonable transfomer plugin by way of it being the first/only transformer installed, or by way of an `alias` or `namespace` value being set to `dbt`. The approaches don't do well if the project _actually_ has >1 transformer installed.

_decoded_content.title: Telemetry project counts inflated if using a custom project_id
_decoded_content.description:
@edgarrmondragon helpfully pointed me to this block in our [tap-gitlab conversation](https://github.com/MeltanoLabs/tap-gitlab/pull/77#discussion_r875020636):

https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/4c8cbc0bdb4db0248a378017c3615d88e8cf1878/src/meltano/core/tracking/ga_tracker.py#L84-95

That block apparently fails initialization of project ID _and creates a new one_ if the project ID is not a valid UUID. In my experience, this was getting written back to my project file and then I would continually revert it and it would reset again, etc. In CI, this probably gets a distinct project ID on each run - meaning each run through CI (and each job) looks like a distinct project.

This is very likely creating a significant inflation of our total domain project IDs and I think we should address as ~"urgency::high". (The code was last touched 12+ months ago, or so, so I imaging this has been an issue for quite a while.)

cc @tayloramurphy, @pnadolny13, @edgarrmondragon, @DouweM

_decoded_content.title: Consider implementing a trackable 'telemetry state change' event for disabling tracking
_decoded_content.description:
As per [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meta/-/issues/232#note_946618166), having a measure of how many projects have disabled tracking is important in distinguishing between opt-out and churn in our user base, and therefore the effectiveness of our onboarding pipelines and the overall stickiness of the Meltano product. In other software service contexts it is common practice to receive an 'unsubscribe' event from the user opting out of future communications, notifications or tracking. In our context this is harder, due to the fact that users can modify the tracking flag 'offline' (directly in their yaml) before Meltano can send its last "user unsubscribed from tracking" event.

<details><summary>Click to expand</summary>


Given that we receive `project_id` in other requests (such as requests to the hub), there is an argument to be made that users aren't truly unsubscribed to tracking unless we have stored a definitive record of that preference. We may inadvertently be tracking projects that have tracking disabled by not capturing this flag explicitly.

This issue is therefore to discuss possible solutions to the "settings changed offline" constraint, with the aim of being able to capture the moment when tracking was disabled in config to deliver a last "project unsubscribed" message.

- A `project.lock` lock file created when the project is initialised, containing a tracking flag (initially on) that is only flipped if Meltano detects a drift in value between the current lock value and config. This allows us to compare the previous 'locked' state of our tracking flag with the users config and send subscribed/unsubscribed events on changes.
  - In plain-json form this is not completely tamper-proof, as users might still edit the lock file value offline at the same time as their config (avoiding a delta and therefore the trigger).
  - Making the flag in the lock file less conspicuous (e.g. by encoding its status in a "project_hash" value) would mitigate this.
- A tracking bit on the `project_id`. This is similar to the "project hash" solution above, except is used as the primary identifier for the project (stored in `meltano.yml`). The idea would be to encode the tracking status into the `project_id` such that Meltano can infer the previous tracking state by inspecting the `project_id` alone. A simplistic encoding scheme example is adding a `1` or `0` to the end of our generated UUID to denote tracking status. By comparing the users configured value to their encoded `project_id` we can detect changes in tracking preferences, in order to trigger subscribe/unsubscribe messages.
  - As a consequence of this, `project_id`'s (becoming essentially a hash) will change every time a user changes their tracking preferences, which is still visible to end users in their git diff (even if the encoding/hashing scheme used is more opaque than the simple 1/0 example).

</details>

----

### 2022-05-23 Update

<details><summary>Click to expand</summary>

Based on feedback from below I think a reasonable proposal is:

* Add a non-obfuscated entry to the project lock file indicating usage stats status
* Payload should be as simple as possible:

```json
{
 "project_id": "<GUID>"
 "disable_tracking": "true"
}
```
* `meltano config meltano set send_anonymous_usage_stats false` would run the check right after updating the setting instead of just at the start of the command
* If a user manually sets it in their yaml file the lock file wouldn't yet be updated so the check would run and fire the event along with the log message
* We should send a resubscribe event along with a log message indicating it was turned back on

</details>


---- 

#### 2022-05-27 Update

_Side note: we cannot call this 'unsubscribe' since that implies a marketing/communication framing which I think is misleading here. Instead, I've renamed this as a 'telemetry state change' event. Rather than 'subscribing' or 'unsubscribing', I think 'opt in' and 'opt out' would be the preferred language._

I think we can combine this with the fixes and improvements described in #3502, will post more detail shortly.

1. We expand contents of `analytics.json` which is created by the code in `ga_tracker.py`:
   - Add `project_id` and `send_anonymous_usage_statistics`. (Currently this only contains a single field `client_id`.)
1. Upon initializing Meltano and checking for the status of `send_anonymous_usage_stats`:
   - If tracking is `disabled` per yaml and/or env var config:
     - If `analytics.json` does not exist: Do nothing.
     - If `analytics.json` does exist, and `send_anonymous_usage_stats` is `False`: Do nothing.
     - If `analytics.json` does exist, and `send_anonymous_usage_stats` is `True`:
       - This means tracking is being disabled after previously being enabled. Send a one-time `telemetry_state_change` event and then update the `analytics.json` contents to reflect the latest values.
   - If tracking is `enabled` per yaml and/or env var config:
     - Update `analytics.json` to include the latest version of `project_id`, `send_anonymous_usage_stats` and `client_id`.
     - If any of the contents of `analytics.json` were changed, send a one-time `telemetry_state_change` event.

Documentation updates:

We may want to let users know that when they have opted in to anonymous usage stats enabled, a one-time event may be sent when opt-in status and/or project_id is changed.

The way for a user to opt out without sending the one time `telemetry_status_change` event:

1. set `send_anonymous_usage_stats` to `false` in `meltano.yml`
2. delete `.meltano/analytics.json`.

If both are performed together, Meltano will not send the a `telemetry_status_change` event (as described by logic above).

_decoded_content.title: Preserve a user accessible snapshot of the v1 docs
_decoded_content.description:
@aaronsteers mentioned in passing the idea that we should try and preserve a snapshot of the v1 docs and make them easily accessible for users so that users still on v1 have a docs reference they can continue to use. 

We've got a few options for doing this, but since it sounds like we may create a dedicated `v1` branch to keep around as a precaution - we could just build and deploy docs from this branch (possibly using [Netlify branch deploys](https://docs.netlify.com/domains-https/custom-domains/multiple-domains/#branch-subdomains)).  Then we could allow users to access the v1 docs via url like https://<branch-name>.docs.meltano.com, and of course link to it from the main docs site as well.

_decoded_content.title: Move discovery.yml to a host we can access logs
_decoded_content.description:
https://gitlab.com/meltano/squared/-/issues/80 is blocked by not having access to logs from Netlify. 

We need to move https://discovery.meltano.com/discovery.yml to a hosting provider where we can access the logs. 

Goals of this would be to:

* Get an estimate of users not on 2.0
* Understand usage patterns of the old discovery.yml in light of the Hub being the SSOT
* Potentially use this data to set a date for full deprecation.

@aaronsteers @afolson I don't have enough experience to know what would be a good option. Can you advise here?

Also @aaronsteers this would be worth getting done for the ~"v2.0" release.

_decoded_content.title: Add job support to schedules and to airflow
_decoded_content.description:
In https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2924 we're adding support for top level jobs concept in meltano.yaml along with adding support for jobs expansion to `meltano run`. We also want to add job support to the `meltano schedule` command, and likely also alter how airflow interacts with schedules ala https://gitlab.com/meltano/files-airflow/-/blob/master/bundle/orchestrate/dags/meltano.py. 

## Some clarification on things that caused confusion in #2924.

1. We are NOT deprecating support `elt` schedules in favor of `run`, and `meltano schedule` including `meltano schedule run` will support both.
2. Airflow calls `meltano schedule run` [per schedule](https://gitlab.com/meltano/files-airflow/-/blob/master/bundle/orchestrate/dags/meltano.py#L99), it does NOT use `meltano elt` directly,  `meltano schedule run` uses MeltanoInvoker to spawn a `meltano elt` subprocess.
   - at a minimum `meltano schedule run` will need to support calling both `meltano elt` and `meltano run` based on the scheduled its being asked to run.

## Latest `meltano schedule` UX spec
(ala @tayloramurphy in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2924#note_937990262)

```
meltano schedule <schedule_name> <job_name> <interval> # This is the default
meltano schedule job add <schedule_name> <job_name> <interval> # This is the same behavior as the above but [job] and [add] are default
meltano schedule elt <schedule_name> <extractor> <loader> <interval> [--transform={run,skip,only}] # new syntax for elt workflows Q: Does this break anything in the UI?
meltano schedule elt add <schedule_name> <extractor> <loader> <interval> [--transform={run,skip,only}] # same as above with the default add
meltano schedule <schedule_name> set <job_name> <interval> <environment>
meltano schedule <schedule_name> set name=<job_name> # this is different from the description b/c of the key (same for the next 2) - Q: Is the key required?
meltano schedule <schedule_name> set interval=<interval>
meltano schedule <schedule_name> set environment=<environment>
meltano schedule list [--format=json] Does this work with jobs that are scheduled via the job definition?
meltano schedule run <schedule_name>
```

_decoded_content.title: ADR: Replace implicit plugin dependencies with explicit inlined reference
2.0 Launch Demo Day Presentation
_decoded_content.description:
During Demo Day, Product should demo all of the wonderful new features of Meltano 2.0. Possible flow:

* start in terminal, show meltano init
* dive into meltano discover - 
  * highlight Hub as SSOT
  * do short tour of the new meltanohub
* install extractor, loader, transformer, utility (GE), superset 
  * probably switch to already installed project to speed up install
* do interactive config of _some_ of these
* highlight lock file
* do a `meltano run`
* launch superset and show off some dashboards built with the data we extracted
* show how we can switch to prod and run this
* show the new jobs and scheduling capability

### What is the "wow" factor of "oh I couldn't do this before Meltano"?

Perhaps some of this could be a fake "here's what we're planning on building soon with Meltano".

* should be some sort of CI test using `meltano test`
  * flow could be that we have a PR open and ready to go
  * could we use the [superset-cli](https://github.com/preset-io/backend-sdk#commands) to do something interesting? my tie into exposures with dbt?
  * another option could be to do a super hacky scan of sources.yml in dbt and compare that to the schema the target has. we could register that as a utility script test



<!-- Labels to add for triaging -->

_decoded_content.title: Make setting-level `env:` declaration a one-way injection into the plugin execution context
_decoded_content.description:
Follows from #3431: We want the `env:` usage pattern to be fully unambiguous. The use case this exists for is so that plugins can receive injected environment variable values from Meltano.

1. The user sets the setting value in any supported way.
2. The plugin gets that setting value from the `env:`.
3. If an env var is already set by that name, its value will be replaced by the setting value.


For example: if the OS context has an env var set as `DEBUG_MODE=1` but my plugin has a setting with `env: DEBUG_MODE` and setting value of `0`, then the plugin when invoked will have `DEBUG_MODE=0`, which is the value that the plugin is intended to receive by the Meltano user. ~~Any other env vars from context will be ignored _unless_ they are referenced under `value:`, `env_aliases:`, or the `config:` entry.~~ Any other env vars from context will be ignored _**when initializing the plugins settings**_ _unless_ they are referenced under `value:`, `env_aliases:`, or the `config:` entry.

_decoded_content.title: When scheduling, `interval: once` might be better expressed as `interval: manual` or `interval: none`
_decoded_content.description:
When scheduling, the "once" interval setting is really a misnomer. It probably should be shown as "manual" or "none".

Most of the time, the "once" setting is used to describe a pipeline that will be triggered manually or by a pipeline/orchestration tool external to meltano. 

Follows from: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3392#note_924105822

## Re: Backwards compatibility

As far as I can tell, there's no need to deprecate `once` and introduce a breaking change here. We could just introduce a new option like "manual", "none", or "never" which functionally would be synonymcs of `once`. We'd then update the default schedule creation logic to prefer the new naming over the old one.

Cc @tayloramurphy, @alex1126
